title: Will Dilma Rousseff cease to be President of Brazil before 1 January 2017?
preds:
According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
Vote was done today!

This is an update not a forecast. 
The party is over, figuratively and in reality, for her in this question.   
She was removed from office earlier today.

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/aug/31/dilma-rousseff-impeached-president-brazilian-senate-michel-temer
Michel Temer confirmed as new president after 61 of 81 senators back Rousseff’s removal from office amid economic decline and bribery scandal

According to multiple sources Dilma Rousseff has now been impeached with 61 senators voting for her impeachment. Although she can appeal to Brazil's highest court, I do not see that as being very likely. I now increase my percentage by 12%.
She lost. There was 61 votes against her, 7 more than needed to remove her from office.

Doesn't seem like her testimony yesterday may a difference or brought her new friends.  Not that it was expected to do so.  The Brazilian senate is hearing final arguments today and may vote tonight or tomorrow. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-30/from-guerrilla-to-impeachment-the-dilma-rousseff-story

Impeachment proceedings are almost always political decisions with a thin veneer of law rather than legal decisions.  That's why they are given to political rather than legal bodies to conduct.  All things considered, this is probably sensible.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The vote is imminent (sorry--upcoming).  A surprise is not expected--but then, it wouldn't be a surprise, would it?  Tchau, Dilma.

I haven't been able to get on in a while but now I am reposting. Since my last update, things have changed a lot regarded Rousseff. The trial will come to a close this week and according to BBC, 52 senators have declared that they will vote for her impeachment. This means that only two more out of the 29 senators will be needed to confirm her impeachment. With this I increase my percentage by 40% leaving me at 69%. Also, because the majority of Brazil is against Rousseff, even if she survives the vote and is reinstated, there is a possibility that she could resign afterward. She has already stated that she would bring a reelection sooner than usual so as to remove the corruption from the government. With this I increase my percentage by 15%. Regardless, I will be waiting for Dilma's defense speech and the reaction of the senators to see if any other changes are necessary.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The Senate has more than the required votes to impeach Rousseff.

The defense makes its case (ex finance minister testifies Rousseff broke no laws):
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/08/brazil-dilma-rousseff-trial-told-broke-laws-160828052638654.html
International support from the entertainment community:
https://www.rt.com/news/357361-chomsky-condemns-impeachment-rousseff/
Rousseff to testify on Monday Aug. 28.:
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/aug/28/rousseff-prepares-to-testify-at-brazil-impeachment-hearing

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-impeachment-idUSKCN11007P
Apparently vote will be next week.  There are many surprising things about Brazil.  This will not be one of them.

Final impeachment proceedings start today and go on until Aug 29.  In order for impeachment to go through, 2/3 of the Brazilian Senate will need to vote to approve it.  Rousseff will be testifying in front of the Senate on Monday and, afterwards, the Senate will vote.

D-Day for Dilma? As her impeachment 'trial' begins, there's no sign that she has gathered enough support to survive as president.
Alarming that such little international concern has been expressed over this whole process. The idea that she will be facing a fair trial - when most senators have already made up their minds - is laughable.

I"m not sure how she could remain in power once the trials begin tomorrow. They don't want her despite this being a common corruption. In fact, that maybe a clear sign of how much is against her, the fact that this is usually ignored, yet, not in her case.
A bunch of corrupt politicians ousting each other as fast as they can... incredible.
The process is steaming full speed ahead; with the trial to begin on 25-Aug, I can't see how it won't be completed by 1-Jan-17.
Time is running out for her and so far the politicians that allowed impeachment have given no signal to reverse it and seem quite happy with Temer

As the summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro end, Brazilians will turn their attention to the start of an impeachment trial Thursday of the nationâ€™s suspended President Dilma Rousseff, who stands accused of violating budget laws.
http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/brazils-president-begin-impeachment-trial/
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The Brazilian senate will impeach her on the 29th of August.

Dilma Rousseff offered an uncommon mea culpa just days before she faces an impeachment trial, saying she made mistakes in choosing a running mate who turned against her and in adopting tax policies, which helped erode public finances.
My estimate is within two or three weeks after the circus leaves town, or no later than first week in October.  I have not checked this carefully with sources in Brazil, though.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

This week, Brazil moved one step closer to removing Dilma Rousseff from office after the Senate voted to indict the suspended president over charges of violating fiscal laws.The move means that the Senate will go ahead with Rousseff's trial, which is expected to begin at the end of August. Rousseff calls the ongoing impeachment proceedings a "coup".
http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/upfront/2016/08/brazil-dilma-impeachment-case-study-hypocrisy-160812113243389.html

She is no longer getting political cover from Lula da Silva, arguably the most popular Brazilian politician in A Really Long Time, as he has his own problems.  After the Olympics crowds leave town, she is--not to put too fine a point on it--toast.
Brazil's Senate voted early today to hold an impeachment trial for the nation's suspended president Dilma Rousseff, a process that could see her permanently removed from office.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-impeachment-vote-idUSKCN10L0HO
The game is afoot.  The timer is set to go off after the Olympics mob are safely out of town, since overlapping demonstrations and street noises are in nobody's interest.  It will not require many days after that to wrap it all up.
Coming up even more to get back to consensus average.

BRASILIA, Brazil - The Brazilian Senate voted Wednesday to an impeachment trial of President Dilma Rousseff that could lead to its final release shortly after the Rio de Janeiro Olympic Games.
http://www.journaldemontreal.com/2016/08/10/bresil-le-senat-decide-de-soumettre-rousseff-a-un-proces-en-destitution
-------------
COMMENT:
I was bold and over consensus on this, my thoughts were that once a leader leave the position of power it is difficult--if not impossible--to take it back. Friends turn foes rather quickly in politics.
The article above doesn't leave to Dilma much room for optimism.
They voted yesterday to start the process.

An article in the FT sadly behind a pay wall unless you sign up for a few free articles per month:
http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/caae055a-5ec7-11e6-bb77-a121aa8abd95.html#axzz4GqC74VUG
Impeachment process approved in Senate with strong majority. Upping expectation to 97%.

Thanks to Annienak for the update on this one.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/299686
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

When Pres Pro-Tem Temer spoke in the 80,000-capacity MacaranÃ£ Stadium there was audible booing and jeering as he declared the Games open, and there's been revelations that he sought & kept illegal campaign contributions, so Brazil hasn't achieved a corruption-less government by putting Rousseff on ice.  Only a couple of votes will need to be flipped to bring her back.  I just down't know, though, if that's in the cards.  Maybe everyone has moved on.  "Neutralizing" my forecast.

Knocking down a tick due to recent revelatation$ about  Temer in Odebrecht plea bargain. http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/brazil-marcelo-odebrecht-reportedly-gave-illegal-funds-to-michel-temer-campaign-2959041/    Temer team says the contributions were legal. But that's what Dilma's crew said too.

"A special committee in Brazil's Federal Senate voted to continue with an impeachment trial against suspended President Dilma Rousseff.
The special impeachment committee voted 14-to-5 on Thursday (August 4) to approve a report that recommends impeachment proceedings against Rousseff over evidence she "failed to comply with tax and budget laws on the issue of additional credit decrees" 
http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2016/08/05/President-Dilma-Rousseff-moves-one-step-closer-to-impeachment-trial/6201470391424/

Still seems to be moving in that direction...
https://news.vice.com/article/brazil-is-very-close-to-impeaching-dilma-rousseff

All signs point to yes after recent s enate vote. But new revelations from "the big O" (Marcelo Odebrecht) about acting prez Temer could weaken his already weak presidency and  quash his and the ambitions of other repectable kleptocrats http://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-corruption-odebrecht-idUSL1N1AM0XG
for the 2018 presidential race.

Rousseff's impeachment trial for violations of budgeting rules is set to begin 29 August. A two-thirds vote by the Senate would remove her from office. Given that she has been put on trial by 2/3rds in the first place, the storm clouds are many.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
the oligarchy has closed ranks against her.  it controls the heights of power and the means of communication (the press).

Dropping a bit for the moment as the momentum for the impeachment begins to slow, and criticism of the impeachment process is beginning to mount. http://www.coha.org/brazilian-prosecutor-declares-dilma-rousseff-not-guilty-of-budgetary-maneuvers/
official terms of impeachment end before 2017 so decision before is very likely. Success of temporary government makes reversal almost impossible

Vote of confidence is very low, standing at about 7%. Low-income class is getting particularly agitated and being hard to silence. Although in the past few months there has been some economic recovery, the country is still very volatile and a potential trigger would surely speed up the process. However it is a country that implements changes slowly, hence my prediction of 77%.
Anti Dilma forces seem to be stronger in the judicial sphere than Dilma supporters, even if the majority of voters support her, which may not be true any longer.

So there doesn't seem to be a legal rationale...
http://www.eurasiareview.com/21072016-brazilian-prosecutor-declares-dilma-rousseff-not-guilty-of-budgetary-maneuvers-oped/
She was a total catastrophe: politically stupid, economically ignorant and personally arrogant. As Claude Hopkins said long ago, "Pilots who prove reckless are forever feared."
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
The impetus against her seems to be running out of credibility.

Dilma has further discredited herself by trying link her  "coup meme"  (impeachment=golpe) with international efforts backing Turkey's "democratically elected leader, ergo if the world supports him, why not me.  Her social media minions jumped on the issue, making noise not getting traction. Brazil's powerful religious, notably the Assemblies of God, of which deposed former house speaker (who led the fight to impeach Dilma) is a member and televangelist, is not making any deals, they want her out and it will be "god's will" ...

Based on the supporting opinions of the judiciary, Rousseff may take some time before the promised election call (if at all).
http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Brazil-Senators-Push-to-End-Impeachment-Against-Rousseff-20160716-0006.html

Going back up to 80% 
Per xcellent points previously in separate analysis made by @scholarandcat fixed term issues & @praedico on elections timing along w/ the numbers crunching probability work @Khalid.

Up to 73% from 55% following Khalid's summary.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/278199
Increasing from 35%, based on the comments following my last post a week ago.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/273245
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

-+1 from 95
«“I’m not even sure she wants to come back,” says Andre Perfeito, senior economist with Gradual Investimentos in São Paulo.  ”If she does, she has already spoken of new elections. And if the senate does overturn her impeachment, then I wouldn’t doubt that the Electoral Court (TSE is the acronym in Brazil) nullifies the entire 2014 election and we get new elections before 2018. It’d be messy.”» [1]
http://www.forbes.com/sites/kenrapoza/2016/07/07/what-happens-in-brazil-if-dilma-returns-to-the-presidency/#3bad63327aee
The legal case is not particularly strong for impeachment so could hang on as President.
Even though Rousseff may avoid impeachment, the promise to hold new elections at a future date, adds further uncertainty.

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-36741532
Coming down some on this and related stories.  However, I think the impeachment process will go forward and result in her leaving office anyway.

Although I think the momentum is still likely to sweep her out of office, the chaos that has erupted on the side of her opponents (particularly Eduardo Cunha stepping down as speaker over his own bribery charges) and the reporting on the lack of substantiating evidence is causing me to lower my forecast probability.

No big shock that Eduardo Cunha - the man who led the impeachment process against Rousseff - has joined the exodus of crooked politicians. It's doubtful he will be the last. Not sure where this leaves Dilma as there is strong political and social momentum to remove her permanently, but maybe - maybe - a vote for impeachment will now seem like making a deal with the devil. Only a minor swing is required to return Rousseff to power, and that's a genuine possibility, but even if she escapes impeachment it's hard to see how she can reestablish her presidency. What a mess!
Estimate changed due to changing conditions within the Senate deliberations

It sounds like Lulu has written her off to me.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/04/brazil-ex-president-luiz-ignacio-lula-da-silva-interview
Back down 25 due to updates from @flyn1200, @scholarandcat &, @Khalid analysis - thx !

Don't know much about this, but I think the consensus of 85% is too high.
Initial forecast at 55%.

@flyn1200 and @scholarandcat
Down further from 65%. With a Senate panel clearing her of manipulating budget figures - one of the major charges against her - there's more reason for a few Senators who initially voted against her to change their minds. To recap, the vote against her was 55-22, just two more than the 54 required to get two thirds of the 81 Senators. If she does cease to be President because of the Senate, it'll be due to her unpopularity, not because of anything she's done. Additionally, it appears as though none of her potential replacements have clean hands either.

http://www.coha.org/dilma-rousseff-found-not-guilty-of-budgetary-maneuvers/
So much of this is political and she was not cleared by the independent auditors on all charges, but the “fiscal pedaling" charge is the big one.

29 June 2016; "Recently, a Senate report cleared Rousseff of any wrongdoing in the budgetary rules case"  Impeachment vote will now be held after the Olympics.
http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Brazil-Delays-Impeachment-Verdict-Until-After-Olympics-Report-20160629-0025.html
-85%
The people want change and the International community is preparing to support a new leader
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

More pressure on  Brazil on international level, something people could understand and react upon. Why give money to Olympics when people need resources? Why did Brazil invest in Olympics? These are the questions that will have popular support against President Rouseff.
Jumping into this question with a 25% hedge against her impeachment.

Early indicator: Cunha appeals, will get up or down vote in lower house. If voted out, house will next vote on a replacement.  Might be a numeric indication of change in positions (at least in the lower house).
http://www.theatlantic.com/news/archive/2016/06/brazil-cunha-rousseff/487136/

Based on:
http://home.bt.com/news/world-news/dilma-rousseff-favours-new-elections-to-overcome-political-weariness-in-brazil-11364068002003
http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/a99eab004d2586e3ae29ae830b7eb7b6/Brazil-interim-President-Temer-sought-illegal-campaign-funds-
http://www.wsj.com/articles/brazils-interim-president-michel-temer-linked-to-corruption-probe-in-plea-bargain-1466022380
and
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-corruption-cunha-idUSKCN0Z02MY?il=0
Thanks to @orchidny , @rene , and @raisinville for the links!

The new cabinet are toddling off to the slammer, just as her one did.  As far as I can tell, though, there is little sentiment among the remaining temporarily unincarcerated legislators for bringing back her lot.  They will go ahead and dump her and then deal with the next crowd after the next round of elections.
The senate will keep his position. It's not a higher probability because car wash investigation can hit Temer

If I correctly heard what was on the BBC tonight while I was cooking, temp Pres Temer has now lost 3 cabinet members because of corruption problems.  It seems like he's not had much success consolidating his power.  Rousseff has to flip only 2 votes.  I think it is do-able.

The interim government is proving to be very corrupt. The cabinet it has named has been very unpopular.  The political situation seems less certain. I will adjust slightly. So far this week, Rousseff had her presidential perks removed.  She has called for a new election or referendum if she's reinstated.
re-adjusting as Brazil is facing lots of civil issues: barrios, zika, superbugs, unstable economy, inflation. environmental, international bad press.
pledged to call new elections - undermines sitting government

In modern era (since last military rule ended) 2 out of 7 Presidents have had powers suspended, Collor and Rousseff. Collor resigned before the impeachment trial which Rousseff has not done. She seems determined to fight this. The impeachment process lasts 180 days from when Rousseff's powers were suspended in May by just achieving the required 2/3 majority in the senate (55 out of 81 senators, minimum 54 required). After the 180 days the same senators have to again vote with a 2/3 majority to remove her permanently from office. Having lived in Brazil on 2 occasions I am sure she's guilty of corruption because all Brazilian politicians are corrupt. But this isn't about evidence or justice it's about political skulduggery. Rousseff's game now will be threatening senators with revealing their own crimes if they vote to remove her. If Rousseff and her political acolytes can threaten enough of them with tit-for-tat exposure and similar treatment she can survive.

Dilma was asked in interview 'would you support new elections' she responded that she must refuse to answer that question because that would indicate that she has given up the fight to be reinstated....she is now publicly supporting new elections.

Brazil's congressional ethics committee votes to strip Speaker, Cunha, of his seat. 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-corruption-cunha-idUSKCN0Z02MY?il=0

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.
News this week on protests in Brazil against Rousseff's removal.
I made a mistake on my forecast a few minutes ago.

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.
News this week on protests in Brazil against Rousseff's removal.

Report on yesterday's pro Rousseff demonstrations.
Article suspects Lula would be the Workers Party candidate in any new election scenario.
http://plus55.com/politics/2016/06/protests-michel-temer-34-cities
If only to strengthen the senate and weaken the president, but there is enough for the senate to impeach her.

At this point, the final judgement will take place in August and 54 votes are necessary to impeach Dilma permanently from the federal government.
The Senate had 55 votes in favor of starting the impeachment process a month ago, so very close to the limit. Using that as a starting point, I would set my initial estimate at 54%.

Rousseff calls for a referendum on new elections; if she survives the impeachment process.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics-idUSKCN0YW1EM
Correcting. Temporary administration has had a poor start, is not in anyway a broad based coalition and the few votes President Rousseff needs may be achievable over the next few months.
GOING DOWN 10 from 60 to 50% well below consensus.
Still a good chance that Temer gets caught up in Lava Jato

Revised estimate due to approximately 50 senators in the Brazilian senate have doubts about the veracity of agreeing to the impeachment due to ongoing high level detentions and evidence of further corruption by the current interim regime.  If these 50 maintain their position, they would only need for more votes to prevent impeachment proceedings continuing.  However, the situation is still fluid, but the situation remains precarious.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics-impeachment-idUSKCN0YT2HD
Not as clear as it once was, but one hears that the notion of giving Temer a chance to see what he can do will probably outweigh the buyer's remorse that might favour Dilma.  Among the folks who will actually vote on this, even her backers, there seems not to be much saudade about Dilma's absence.  "Já é suficiente" perhaps sums it up better.
Senate leaders said on Monday that the impeachment trial was expected to conclude sometime in early August.
Looks like 24% forecast may be too high, reducing to 5%.

It no longer matters whether Rousseff's suspension was legitimate or whether she can avoid a two-thirds pro-impeachment majority in the senate. Barring a major upswing in popular sentiment, she's done. 
That the impeachment trial has been prioritized by Temer's politburo is, I think, a sign of either fear or desperation. I really didn't expect it to happen so soon, but it does seem likely that the longer this drags on, the better Rousseff's chances would be and that possibility is clearly to be avoided at all costs. Is the plan now to 'bury' the proceedings and verdict with a happy layer of Olympics fever? 
There is still a reasonable chance that Dilma can avoid impeachment, but even so, where to from there? Forget the two-thirds majority for a guilty verdict - Rousseff would probably need close to a 50-50 split (highly unlikely) to be able to build a relatively effective presidency. 
I honestly don't know where Brazil goes from here. Impeachment won't be the end of the awkward questions and it's impossible to see Temer's ill-gotten government surviving another twelve months.
Down another 5% Come down 2%. Sort of impressed w/ @Gibson quote! https://vine.co/v/iUEVd17MTFT (who needs the invisible hand when you have the hand of god)

Forbes article claims global investors have put Temer on notice.  News from Brazil is not positive and investors are concerned.
http://www.forbes.com/sites/kenrapoza/2016/06/02/global-investors-put-brazils-interim-president-michel-temer-on-notice/#1241a4f87336

A month ago I though she was finished. However, with recent revelations that members of the caretaker cabinet may have pushed for Dilma's impeachment because the anti-corruption investigation was getting too close to them, it is likely that some of the senators who voted for her trial may eventually decide not to find her guilty. The whole impeachment saga has so far been driven more by her general unpopularity than any real wrong-doing, whereas several of those opposing her are facing real charges of corruption.
According to general news and GJP consensus.

Quick adjustment: according to an article shared with me by @Shiva-Diva, Rousseff has 22 of the 28 votes she needs to prevent impeachment. With only 6 votes needed, it does not seem that impossible for Rousseff to achieve. She also stated that two members of the senate that had previously been on board with the impeachment are now reconsidering due to the released recordings involving two of Temer's cabinet members.
- If two-thirds of 81 senators then support impeachment, she will be permanently removed from office.
After 37 requests the impeachment process was voted by the two thirds needed just once.
Since the start of the New Republic in Brazil, out of the 5 presidents (not including Rousseff), only 1 has been impeached so my baseline estimate is at 20%.
In light of gjo options that see her not in office  other than impeachment I'm dropping my prediction

Brazilian Court bars Temer from running for political office for the next 8 years due to violations of election law.
http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Literally-Unelectable-Court-Bars-Temer-from-Running-for-Office-20160603-0016.html
No news since last week to change my forecast.
The vote to impeach was 54 or 55. She only needs to turn 2 votes to get under the 60% threshold and resume duties as president. With opposition crumbling, this might be possible.
Given the events of the past week; suspect that the chances of an actual impeachment trial may be diminished.

The 0.8% quarter-on-quarter fall in output to be announced today would be horrible news in a normal country. But in Brazil’s case it counts as mildly cheerful: in the previous three quarters the decline ranged from 1.4% to 2.1%. Dilma Rousseff, who as president sent unemployment soaring and incomes tumbling, is now watching from the sidelines pending an impeachment hearing. Her office is occupied by Michel Temer, her ex-deputy, now foe. He hopes that competent economists in his caretaker administration—and a bold plan to fix Brazil’s wobbly public finances—will jolt the economy back to life. It has been a rocky start. Two ministers have resigned in as many weeks after leaked tapes suggested they were trying to hamper a bribery probe in which both government and opposition parties are enmeshed (everyone involved denies wrongdoing). Planting seeds for growth is hard when you are busy putting out fires

It depends if the lower house can get away with nullifying the vote from before. There are some legitimate complaints about it, but I don't believe that they will be able to overturn it. In which case, the upper house will vote, likely with the same outcome, and she will likely be impeached. It will be late in the year, but by November I'd expect her to be impeached.

Eurasia sustains 20% of chance that the Senate rejects her impeachment.
As a Brazilian, local news have been turning somewhat worse in the last few days for Temer.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-corruption-idUSKCN0YL1SB
Temer's Minister of Transparancy resigns over recordings indicating possible participation in efforts to obstruct the  Prtrobras corruption investigations.
From the article: "But the recordings add weight to the argument that the new government could face declining support for Rousseff's ouster by the Senate, which needs a two-thirds majority to convict...."

Current government is facing problems in the Senate, where it will need 2/3 of the votes to impeach Dilma by Aug/Sep.
Adjusting to be below consensus.

Another one bites the dust. . . Anti-corruption (!) minister Fabiano Silveira becomes the second member of the interim government to resign, and there are strong signs he won't be the last. Temer's hand-picked (?) cabinet is in tatters and it is by no means certain that the Senate will gather the two-thirds majority necessary for impeachment. Yes, a majority of Brazilians still believe Rousseff deserves to be removed, but the prescribed grounds for that removal now look exceedingly tainted. An early election appears increasingly likely. Staying above 50% for now because anything is possible in this clown circus, and because a return to real democracy would almost certainly see the end of Rousseff's tenure.
No news since last week to change my forecast.

The state of Rio de Janeiro missed an $8.4 million payment to an international creditor as a debt crisis in Brazil’s state governments deepened amid what the federal Finance Ministry has called “out-of-control personnel expenditures.”
http://www.wsj.com/articles/brazils-rio-de-janeiro-state-misses-debt-payment-1464191036
==============
These are  all bad news for Dilma. She would get a lot of blame now that she is no longer sitting right in there
Down 5% due to phone taps that implicate the president of the Senate. The Senate vice-president is from Dilma's PT party.

More details concerning the alleged coup are becoming public news.  Temer's gov't has lost the Green Party.
Given the 55-22 Senate vote; only 2 votes need to change For the impeachment to fail, if it even gets to a final vote.
http://sputniknews.com/news/20160526/1040257447/dilma-temer-calheiros-juca-cunha.html
http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/3/dd59e7da-2279-11e6-aa98-db1e01fabc0c.html#axzz49mY72E2N

http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-05/26/c_135389649.htm
"The impeachment effort against suspended President Dilma Rousseff may reach a final decision in August, according to a work schedule presented Wednesday by Senator Antonio Anastasia, rapporteur of the current Procedural Commission for the Impeachment," the agency said.
...
On Aug. 1 or Aug. 2, congress would vote on the commission's findings via a simple majority vote of "half of all senators attending plus one."
Come down 2%. Sort of impressed w/ @Gibson quote! https://vine.co/v/iUEVd17MTFT (who needs the invisible hand when you have the hand of god)

I don't know. It's so difficult to judge politics in foreign lands, if you are not there and never have been. Can we assume that those senators who voted to impeach Rousseff will vote to convict her? Brazilian politics seems to change directions with the wind. Rousseff looks pretty good next to acting President Temer and the Planning Minister and ex-senator who were chatting about removing Rousseff from office in order to scupper a corruption investigation of Petrobras. Perhaps that won't matter, unless Brazilians can find a better target of their frustration. Maybe people just expected too much of Rousseff, so now they don't like her and want to see her go. It would help to sway some senators in her favor, if she were more popular in the streets.
https://vine.co/v/iUEVd17MTFT (who needs the invisible hand when you have the hand of god)

Dropping 5% following news of Juca's resignation in wake of leaked tape scandal. Will wait and see how much collateral damage results from this bombshell, but whole impeachment process will surely be scrutinized very closely in the media and in the streets. Temer's government now appears shaky and calls for an early election are likely to grow. Not sure as yet how this will affect Rousseff, though it does lend credibility to her coup accusations and credibility is in short supply right now.

It seems fairly likely that Rousseff will be impeached, but I'm starting my forecast a little lower than the rest of the crowd. If the past six months of following (or at least trying to follow) Brazilian politics has taught me anything, we will likely see a couple of more twists and turns in the plot before before the year is out.

My initial baseline forecast was set at 20% chance of Rousseff being impeached because of the past presidents of Brazil's new republic, and ignoring Rousseff, 1/5 have been impeached. But after being put on trial I raise my probability much higher, at 80%. Rousseff is facing corruption charges but many of her accusers have also been accused of corruption so I don't raise my estimate to anywhere in the 90s.

Still a few questions to be answered before this one is a done deal. International reaction, esp. China. Effectiveness of Temer administration. Olympics. Illegality of Rousseff's actions? (Impeachable?) Culture of corruption. If she is willing to stay in the fight, she may yet draw popular and political support.

The Senate voted to proceed with a larger margin than needed to convict.  It is pretty much in the nature of impeachment & removal proceedings that votes don't change just because of the trial.  The courts are sort of a wild card in this, but if they throw the case out, it is not unlikely that the political machinery will think of something else that will work.
55 Senators voted to suspend her from office early this morning. It will take 54 votes in October or November to remove her. So the votes are there.

Brazil’s president is ousted.
Senators voted this morning after a marathon session to suspend Dilma Rousseff and begin an impeachment trial against her.
Lawmakers accepted the charges accusing her of borrowing from state banks to conceal a fiscal deficit. We expect her to speak today as she leaves the presidential palace
----

Trial can take up to 180 days, but there is enough time left for it to happen this year.

Senate has voted to impeach, 55-22.  The trial has to be completed within six months, which means that if found guilty she'll cease to be President before the end of the year. A reasonable first assumption must be that all those who voted to impeach her will also vote to find her guilty. If there are any surprises that change this prediction, there should be more than enough time to adjust.

I won’t be swept under the carpet,” Brazil’s president has vowed. She is nevertheless likely to be brushed aside today. The Senate looks poised to begin her impeachment trial, ostensibly over dodgy government accounting, ignoring Monday’s abortive attempt by Waldir Maranhão, the acting lower-house speaker, to halt proceedings on procedural grounds. Brazilians are rightly fed up with Ms Rousseff’s economic ineptitude and with corruption in her Workers’ Party—indeed, with the whole self-serving political class. They want fresh faces. The main sweepers would be capable—Michel Temer, the canny vice-president who would take her place; Henrique Meirelles, a former central-bank governor, as finance chief; and José Serra, a senior opposition senator, as foreign minister—but they are in their 70s. Since 1985 the vice-president’s centrist (and hardly squeaky-clean) party has rarely been out of government. Brazilians can be forgiven their scepticism: just 8% think he will do a better job than Ms Rousseff
